entry.title: Arabic - day 02
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • typed a dialogue

  • read out loud

I’ve read about half of the chapter in Teach Yourself Arabic and it seems to be a tad too long to do a chapter a day.

I didn’t have enough time to learn today, so I only did some reading, typing and Anki vocab repeating.

Dialogue

عَفْضَت، كَم السَّاعَة الآن؟

السَّاعَة السَّادِسَة بَعد الظُّهرِ

كَم السَّاعَة الآن فِي نيو يورك؟

فِي نيو يورك السَّاعَة العَاشِرَة الآن

صَبَاحاً أَم مَسَاءً؟

صَبَاحاً

وكَم السَّاعَة الآن فِي طوكيو؟

فِي طوكيو السَّاعَة الآن الثَانِيَة لَيْلاً فِي اليَوم التَّالي

أَيْ عِندَنَا يَوْم الأَربَعَاء وفِي اليابان يَوْم الخَمِيس؟

نَعم

وما هُوَ الفَصل هُناك الآن؟

نَمَا هُوَ عِندَنَا. ولَكِن فِي الأَرجَنتِين الآن فَصل الشِّتَاء

entry.title: Arabic - day 01
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • created a new Arabic deck

  • typed a dialog

  • read out loud

It was an easy first day - I concentrated mostly on reading properly out loud and reminding myself of common phrases. Practiced typing.

Tomorrow I’d like to finish introductory lesson in Teach yourself Arabic and do another dialog from the Polish Arabic learning book.

I’d also like to create my own Markdown editor supporting RTL languages.

Dialogue

كاشا: أَدْرُسُ اللُّغَةَ الْعَرَبِيَّةَ.

سَمِيرٌ: فِي أَيِّ مَْْعْهَدٍ؟

كاشا: فِي مَعْهَدِ الدِّرَاسَاتِ الشَّرْقِيَّةِ (فِي مَعْهَدِ الأَلْسِنَةِ).

entry.content:

  17. laptop/computer جِهاز حاسوب نَقّال/حاسوب / كُمْبيوتر
  18. visualization تصور
  19. data مَعْلومات / بَيانات
  20. database قَاعِدة مَعْلومات / بَيانات
  21. analysis تَحْليل

  23. Internet الإنْتَرنِت

Motivation

Why am I learning Arabic?

  • I love the sound of it

  • I want to read it

  • I want to enjoy the culture

  • I want to travel to Arabic speaking countries

  • I love writing it

  • I’ve studied and failed

  • I need my passion back

Excuses

What excuses hold me back?

  • I’m too busy

  • I don’t have the money

  • I’ve failed a few times

  • I don’t think I can do it

  • I don’t have anyone to talk to

  • I don’t have a system

  • I will fail

entry.title: A plan is a plan
entry.content:
I’ve decided to relearn Arabic this year, as I’ve completely forgotten the language and I regret it every day. Since I haven’t done systematic learning in a while, I need to follow some steps and have a plan.

The goal

To understand intermediate level conversations in Arabic - be able to watch tv series and follow the plot, listen to the news, ask for help.

To talk about my passions and work.

To read books in Arabic.

To communicate with a native speaker.

What I’ve done so far

  • I read a few articles on TextFugu - a book for Japanese self-learners - mostly on how to get started and motivate myself

  • I noted down my reasons and motivations along with my fears

  • I created my first Anki deck for software-related terms

  • I organized my many Arabic learning books

  • I took my Arabic keyboard cover and put it on my laptop

  • I’ve created this dedicated blog

  • I’ve done some Google searching on Arabic resources, self-learning, motivation and touch-typing

The Plan

Minimum

  • Learn Arabic every day for 52 minutes:
    • Do one lesson from any of my many resources
    • Create an Anki deck with the words
    • Write a blog post for my learning log

  • Once a week watch a short video in Arabic

  • Once a week listen to a podcast/audiobook in Arabic

  • Practice touch-typing an hour a week (can be 10-minute bursts)

  • Go through Anki decks during coding idle time

Additional ideas

  • Read a chapter of a book in Arabic

  • Translate a short article/poem to or from Arabic

  • Draw a detailed picture with annotations for my own picture dictionary

  • Try to speak/write Arabic in a real-life setting

  • Translate song lyrics

  • Find a new resources
